00028 /* system call codes -- used by the stubs to tell the kernel which system call
00029  * is being asked for
00030  */
00031 #define SC_Halt          0 
00032 #define SC_Exit          1 
00033 #define SC_Exec          2 
00034 #define SC_Join          3 
00035 #define SC_Create        4 
00036 #define SC_Open          5 
00037 #define SC_Read          6 
00038 #define SC_Write         7 
00039 #define SC_Seek          8
00040 #define SC_Close         9 
00041 #define SC_NewThread     10 
00042 #define SC_Yield         11
00043 #define SC_PError        12
00044 #define SC_P             13 
00045 #define SC_V             14
00046 #define SC_SemCreate     15 
00047 #define SC_SemDestroy    16
00048 #define SC_LockCreate    17 
00049 #define SC_LockDestroy   18 
00050 #define SC_LockAcquire   19 
00051 #define SC_LockRelease   20 
00052 #define SC_CondCreate    21 
00053 #define SC_CondDestroy   22 
00054 #define SC_CondWait      23 
00055 #define SC_CondSignal    24
00056 #define SC_CondBroadcast 25
00057 #define SC_TtySend       26

00065 #ifndef IN_ASM
00066 
00067 /* The system call interface.  These are the operations the Nachos
00068  * kernel needs to support, to be able to run user programs.
00069  *
00070 
00071  */
00072 
00073 /* Stop Nachos, and print out performance stats */
00074 void Halt();            
00075  
00076 
00077 /* Return the time spent running Nachos */
00078 
00080 typedef struct {
00081   long seconds;
00082   long nanos;
00083 } Nachos_Time;
00084 void SysTime(Nachos_Time *t);
00085 
00086 /* Address space control operations: Exit, Exec, and Join */
00087 
00088 /* This user program is done (status = 0 means exited normally). */
00089 void Exit(int status);  
00090 
00091 /* A unique identifier for a thread executed within a user program */
00092 typedef int ThreadId;   
00093  
00094 /* Run the executable, stored in the Nachos file "name", and return the 
00095  * master thread identifier
00096  */
00097 ThreadId Exec(char *name);
00098 
00099 /* Create a new thread in the current process
00100  * Return thread identifier
00101  */
00102 ThreadId NewThread(char * debugName, int func, int arg);
00103  
00104 /* Only return once the the thread "id" has finished. 
00105  */
00106 int Join(ThreadId id);
00107 
00108 /* Yield the CPU to another runnable thread, whether in this address space 
00109  * or not. 
00110  */
00111 void Yield();           
00112 
00114 void PError(char *mess); 
00115 
00116 /* File system operations: Create, Open, Read, Write, Seek, Close
00117  * These functions are patterned after UNIX -- files represent
00118  * both files *and* hardware I/O devices.
00119  *
00120  * If this assignment is done before doing the file system assignment,
00121  * note that the Nachos file system has a stub implementation, which
00122  * will work for the purposes of testing out these routines.
00123  */
00124  
00125 /* A unique identifier for an open Nachos file. */
00126 typedef int OpenFileId; 
00127 
00128 /* when an address space starts up, it has two open files, representing 
00129  * keyboard input and display output (in UNIX terms, stdin and stdout).
00130  * Read and Write can be used directly on these, without first opening
00131  * the console device.
00132  */
00133 #define ConsoleInput    0  
00134 #define ConsoleOutput   1  
00135  
00136 /* Create a Nachos file, with "name" */
00137 int Create(char *name,int size);
00138 
00139 /* Open the Nachos file "name", and return an "OpenFileId" that can 
00140  * be used to read and write to the file.
00141  */
00142 OpenFileId Open(char *name);
00143 
00144 /* Write "size" bytes from "buffer" to the open file. */
00145 int Write(char *buffer, int size, OpenFileId id);
00146 
00147 /* Read "size" bytes from the open file into "buffer".  
00148  * Return the number of bytes actually read -- if the open file isn't
00149  * long enough, or if it is an I/O device, and there aren't enough 
00150  * characters to read, return whatever is available (for I/O devices, 
00151  * you should always wait until you can return at least one character).
00152  */
00153 int Read(char *buffer, int size, OpenFileId id);
00154 
00155 /* Seek to a specified offset into an opened file */
00156 int Seek(int offset, OpenFileId id);
00157 
00158 #ifndef SYSDEP_H
00159 /* Close the file, we're done reading and writing to it. */
00160 int Close(OpenFileId id);
00161 #endif // SYSDEP_H
00162 
00163 /* Remove the file */
00164 int Remove(char* name);
00165 
00166 /******************************************************************/
00167 /* system calls concerning directory management */
00168 
00169 /* Create a new repertory 
00170    Return a negative number if an error ocurred.
00171 */
00172 int Mkdir(char* name);
00173 
00174 /* Destroy a repertory, which must be empty.
00175    Return a negative number if an error ocurred.
00176 */
00177 int Rmdir(char* name);
00178 
00179 /* List the content of NachOS FileSystem */
00180 void FSList();
00181 
00182 /******************************************************************/
00183 /* User-level synchronization operations :  */
00184  
00185 /* System calls concerning semaphores management */
00186 
00187 typedef int SemId;
00188 
00189 /* Create a semaphore, initialising it at count.
00190    Return a Semid, which will enable to do operations on this
00191    semaphore                                                      */
00192 SemId SemCreate(char * debug_name, int count);
00193 
00194 /* Destroy a semaphore identified by sema. 
00195    Return a negative number if an error occured during the destruction */
00196 int SemDestroy(SemId sema);
00197 
00198 /* Do the operation P() on the semaphore sema */
00199 int V(SemId sema);
00200 
00201 /* Do the operation V() on the semaphore sema */
00202 int P(SemId sema);
00203 
00204 /* System calls concerning locks management */
00205 typedef int LockId;
00206 
00207 /* Create a lock.
00208  Return an identifier */
00209 LockId LockCreate(char * debugName);
00210 
00211 /* Destroy a lock.
00212    Return a negative number if an error ocurred
00213    during the destruction. */
00214 int LockDestroy(LockId id);
00215 
00216 /* Do the operation Acquire on the lock id.
00217    Return a negative number if an error ocurred. */
00218 int LockAcquire(LockId id);
00219 
00220 /*  Do the operation Release  on the lock id.
00221    Return a negative number if an error ocurred.
00222 */
00223 int LockRelease(LockId id);
00224 
00225 /* System calls concerning conditions variables. */
00226 typedef int CondId;
00227 
00228 /* Create a new condition variable */
00229 CondId CondCreate(char * debugName);
00230 
00231 /* Destroy a condition variable.
00232    Return a negative number if an error ocurred.
00233 */
00234 int CondDestroy(CondId id);
00235 
00236 /* Do the operation Wait on a condition variable,
00237    and release the lock which was holded by the 
00238    current thread.
00239    Return a negative number if an error ocurred.
00240 */
00241 int CondWait(CondId cond);
00242 
00243 /* Do the operation Signal on a condition variable. 
00244    The lock must be held by the current thread.
00245    Return a negative number if an error ocurred.
00246 */
00247 int CondSignal(CondId cond);
00248 
00249 /* Do the operation Signal on a condition variable. 
00250    The lock must be held by the current thread.
00251    Return a negative number if an error ocurred.
00252 */
00253 int CondBroadcast(CondId cond);
00254 
00255 /******************************************************************/
00256 /* System calls concerning serial port and console */
00257 
00258 /* Send the message on the (ligne serie).
00259    Return a negative number if an error ocurred.
00260 */
00261 int TtySend(char *mess);
00262 
00263 /* Wait for a message comming from  (ligne serie).
00264    This system call only returns when (blabla) 
00265    The lenght of the message is specified in the system call.
00266    Return a negative number if an error ocurred.
00267 */
00268 int TtyReceive(char *mess,int length);

00270 #endif // IN_ASM
